{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3604574,"name":"Ian Osborn","username":"Sands","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-26T15:49:11.109Z","cooked":"

The Average Joes are proud to share our 2025 Robot - “StingRay”

Onshape CAD

At the start of the season our goals:

  • Win our hosted Week 2 event
  • Impact Contention
  • Intentionally limit complexity (We have a young build team)
  • Robust robot
  • Lean into our more experienced code team.

At the week 2 event, we ranked #2 and took home the banner with 2767 Stryke Force, 7210 RoboJackets, and 6588 Counter-Torque Robotics.

Our Impact team (after ~5-6 years of hard work) took home the Impact Banner. (at this point in the season we already exceeded expectations).

At the excellent week 4 event, hosted by 3604 Goon Squad at Woodhaven HS, we ranked #4 (#1 EPA) and we where the 1st pick by 245 Atombots, again taking home the banner with the more than capable assistance of 6029 Railbots.

At States, on the Consumers Field, we placed #8, with one of the leading EPAs. 5460 Strike Zone (#1 captain), chose us as their 1st pick. Again, we took home the division banner with Strike Zone and 2690 Automation Nation.

We where promptly shown the door on the FIMstein field by the eventual state champs 67 The HOT Team, 2767 Stryke Force, 5843 Flurb.

Our Impact team killed it again, taking home one of 4 banners at States.

So a 5 banner year! (we’d normally win a banner every other year or so)

======

Back to the robot:

Our goals deliberately constrained scope of the robot based on our team’s size and manufacturing capacity.

For our manufacturing base, we have two CNC routers (full sheet and a table top) and a few sponsors that can supply us with lasered AL parts (Tig-Master, Fortress) and Polycarbonate (Midwest Glass). Our other sponsors, Whirlpool, Bosch, St. Joseph School Foundation, are core funding and moral support.

We’ve always had a hard time tuning ground intakes, so we stayed with the coral source load. Our more experienced coders enabled auto scoring for the Reef. (We knew that the high end teams would do ground coral, but again, deliberate constraints to win week 2. Our focus was on simplicity.)

The elevator started as the Thrifty Bot CAD model and parts.

The “shoulder” gearbox was over designed and we use a lot of polycarbonate throughout. For items like the Coral/Algae end effector, this provided for impact resistance when the robot was inevitably crashed into the reef or barge. We borrowed a lot from the WCP concept. The ground Algae intake is a simple slap down. The shoulder gearbox was the only 100% new design on the robot.

The other lesson we learned the hard way in prior years was to have direct shaft measurement for anything that rotates. So encoders on every shaft.

One of the build lessons we learned this year was to pre design as much as possible. The Chassis model is around 2 years old for us. Fully parametric, so chassis perimeter changes are a couple of numbers in a table. The Elevator was Thrifty Bot’s model. The end effector was mainly WCP’s.

We used a ground Algae intake only a few times through the season as we where typically the Coral>>Reef, and then the Reef Algae >> Barge robot as the season matured. Our “taffy puller” climber disallowed ground Algae >> Barge even though the end effector could do that. (the climber took up the same space that the algae claw would occupy.) We didn’t have the weight budget, or the time, to do a climber with the ground Algae intake chin up concept.

Shown the CAD assembly “Master” is a ground coral >> L1 intake. We never mounted that as we just ran out of time between maintenance, code refinement, and driver practice. We actually built it, and we may use it at offseason events. The implemented algae intake is in the assembly “Master Old”. (Master Old also shows earlier versions of the Coral end effector and a version of a climber carabiner that we never implemented).

The main changes through the season where around the code base so Vision localization, autos, and driver aids. Mechanically we revised the Coral / Algae end effector around 6-8 times. Subtle changes for more robust load and better algae handling.

A big off-seasons project is going to be multi-camera localization and more “on the shelf” CAD designs.

Oh, the name - 'cause the kids liked the car, the logo, and the climber sort of looks like a stingray’s tail barbs.

I forgot to add the cherry on top of the season.

When we where planning for Worlds, we thought that we would have a long outside shot at being a captain. Then the assignments drop and we’re assigned to Archimedes. Great! Nice round up there.

Then we get the schedule and StatBotics posted their Strength of Schedule stats. (cue tiny violins)… 0.87 - We had the 3rd hardest schedule! So that plan goes out the window. hahaha

So we just go in and play our game and have fun. We still had nice scores and our EPA was around where we where for DCMP. Reliable, no real mistakes, playing well with others, enjoying the circus, team meals, etc. etc.

Draft time comes up and AT BEST we’re hoping for a late 2nd or 3rd pick. Get to the top of the draft and the 2nd to last spot with Miss Daisy 341 (A Hall of Fame team) picks us up! Wooo Hooo! So what if we’re the spare bot?!? Had a great time hanging out. Helped out 4270 - Crusaders with some spares and some tools. Watched the high end play from ring side, etc. etc.
